subject: Re: [junit] Re: running a single test case in a separate JVM or ClassLoader
msgSnippet: I can t change the design of the class under test, its behavior is defined by a standard. As for different suites, are you suggesting that I separate the tests
messageBody:
I can't change the design of the class under test, its behavior is defined
by a standard.

As for different suites, are you suggesting that I separate the tests
into different groups, and then run each group of tests as a separate
run from maven, each in its own JVM? The number of classes I'd like
to test this way is quite large. I think having lots of different test
suites would quickly become unmanageable.

If I need to build this capability myself, would building my own custom
Runner be the right approach? If so, is there some documentation on how
to write a custom Runner? Or do I just need to read the code?


yme0987654321 wrote on 12/10/2009 08:23 PM:
>
>
> The way I would handle this is to inject the relevant properties via a
> properties object, and then in production pass System.getProperties(),
> that way the tests are not coupled to the nasty global which is the
> System property.
>
> If that isn't an option for some reason, perhaps you can organize your
> different tests into suites, and set the system property in a
> @BeforeClass method on the suite?
>
> Yishai
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>, Bill
> Shannon <Bill.Shannon@...> wrote:
> >
> > I've read the FAQ and the javadocs and done much web searching but
> can't find
> > an answer to this. Sorry if this is stupid question.
> >
> > I need to write a test case that tests a class whose behavior depends on
> > a System property. The class reads the System property at class
> initialization
> > time. I'd like to have multiple test cases, each of which sets a
> different
> > value for the System property, so each of the tests needs to be run in a
> > separate JVM or possibly a separate ClassLoader.
> >
> > Is there a simple way to (e.g.) annotate my test case to cause JUnit to
> > handle this for me?
> >
> > I'm invoking JUnit as part of a maven build. Note that I don't want to
> > run *all* of my JUnit tests in a single separate JVM, I want to run
> > certain test cases each in their own separate JVM (or ClassLoader).
> >
> > If I have to start a new JVM or create a new ClassLoader myself, what's
> > the best way to initialize the CLASSPATH and find the class to be tested
> > from within a JUnit test case running under maven?
> >
> > Thanks.
> >
>
>
